Let $A,B\subset \mathbb{R}^2$ be disjoint sets of size $n$ and $n-3$ respectively, with not all of $A$ contained on a single line. Is there a line which contains at least two points from $A$ and no points from $B$?



Conjectured by Erd\H{o}s and Purdy \cite{ErPu95} (the prize is for a proof or disproof). A construction of Hickerson shows that this fails with $n-2$. A result independently proved by Beck \cite{Be83} and Szemer\'{e}di and Trotter \cite{SzTr83} (see [211]) implies it is true with $n-3$ replaced by $cn$ for some constant $c>0$.

This has been disproved by Xichuan in the comments, who has found three explicit counterexamples. It remains possible that this holds with $n-4$ (or in general with $n-O(1)$ or $(1-o(1))n$).




References


[Be83] Beck, J\'{o}zsef, On the lattice property of the plane and some problems of Dirac, Motzkin and Erd\H{o}s in combinatorial geometry. Combinatorica (1983), 281-297.

[ErPu95] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Purdy, G., Two combinatorial problems in the plane. Discrete Comput. Geom. (1995), 441-443.

[SzTr83] Szemer\'{e}di, Endre and Trotter, Jr., William T., Extremal problems in discrete geometry. Combinatorica (1983), 381-392.
